Communication-efficient Vertical Federated Learning via Compressed Error Feedback

Abstract

Communication overhead is a known bottleneck in federated learning (FL). To address this, lossy compression is commonly used on the information communicated between the server and clients during training. In horizontal FL, where each client holds a subset of the samples, such communication-compressed training methods have recently seen significant progress. However, in their vertical FL counterparts, where each client holds a subset of the features, our understanding remains limited. To address this, we propose an error feedback compressed vertical federated learning (EFVFL) method to train split neural networks. In contrast with previous communication-compressed methods for vertical FL, EFVFL does not require a vanishing compression error for the gradient norm to converge to zero for smooth nonconvex problems. By leveraging error feedback, our method can achieve a ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/T) convergence rate in the full-batch case, improving over the state-of-the-art ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) rate under ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) compression error, and matching the rate of uncompressed methods. Further, when the objective function satisfies the Polyak-Åojasiewicz inequality, our method converges linearly. In addition to improving convergence rates, our method also supports the use of private labels. Numerical experiments show that EFVFL significantly improves over the prior art, confirming our theoretical results.

1 Introduction

Federated learning (FL) is a machine learning paradigm where a set of clients holding local datasets collaborate to train a model without exposing their local dataÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017). FL can be divided into two categories, based on how the data is partitioned across the clients: horizontal FL, where each client holds a different set of samples but all clients share the same features, and vertical FL, where each client holds a different subset of features but all clients share the same samples. Note that we cannot gather and redistribute the data because it must remain at the clients. Thus, we do not choose under which category a given task falls. Rather, the category is a consequence of how the data arises.

In this work, we focus on vertical FL (VFL)Â (Liu etÂ al., 2024). In VFL, a global datasetÂ ğ’Ÿ={ğƒn}n=1Nğ’Ÿsuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğƒğ‘›ğ‘›1ğ‘\mathcal{D}=\{\bm{\xi}_{n}\}_{n=1}^{N} with Nğ‘N samples is partitioned by features across a set of clientsÂ [K]â‰”{1,â€¦,K}â‰”delimited-[]ğ¾1â€¦ğ¾[K]\coloneqq\{1,\dots,K\}. Each sample has Kğ¾K disjoint blocks of features ğƒn=(ğƒnâ€‹1,â€¦,ğƒnâ€‹K)subscriptğƒğ‘›subscriptğƒğ‘›1â€¦subscriptğƒğ‘›ğ¾\bm{\xi}_{n}=(\bm{\xi}_{n1},\dots,\bm{\xi}_{nK}) and the local dataset of each clientÂ kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K] is ğ’Ÿk={ğƒnâ€‹k}n=1Nsubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptsubscriptğƒğ‘›ğ‘˜ğ‘›1ğ‘\mathcal{D}_{k}=\{\bm{\xi}_{nk}\}_{n=1}^{N}, where ğ’Ÿ=â‹ƒkğ’Ÿkğ’Ÿsubscriptğ‘˜subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}=\bigcup_{k}\mathcal{D}_{k}. Since different datasetsÂ ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} have different features, VFL suits collaborations of clients with complementary types of information, who tend to have fewer competing interests. This can lead to a greater incentive to collaborate, compared to horizontal FL. A common application of VFL is in settings where multiple entities own distinct features concerning a shared set of users and seek to collaboratively train a predictor; for example, WeBank partners with other companies to jointly build a risk model from data regarding shared customersÂ (Cheng etÂ al., 2020).

To jointly train a model fromÂ {ğ’Ÿk}subscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\{\mathcal{D}_{k}\} without sharing local data, split neural networksÂ (Ceballos etÂ al., 2020) are often considered. To learn the parameters ğ’™ğ’™\bm{x} of such models, we aim to solve the following nonconvex optimization problem:

minğ’™âˆˆâ„dâ¡fâ€‹(ğ’™)â‰”1Nâ€‹âˆ‘n=1NÏ•nâ€‹(ğ’™0,ğ’‰1â€‹nâ€‹(ğ’™1),â€¦,ğ’‰Kâ€‹nâ€‹(ğ’™K)),â‰”subscriptğ’™superscriptâ„ğ‘‘ğ‘“ğ’™1ğ‘superscriptsubscriptğ‘›1ğ‘subscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›subscriptğ’™0subscriptğ’‰1ğ‘›subscriptğ’™1â€¦subscriptğ’‰ğ¾ğ‘›subscriptğ’™ğ¾\min_{\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}}\;f(\bm{x})\coloneqq\frac{1}{N}\sum_{n=1}^{N}\phi_{n}\left(\bm{x}_{0},\bm{h}_{1n}(\bm{x}_{1}),\dots,\bm{h}_{Kn}(\bm{x}_{K})\right), (1)

where ğ’™â‰”(ğ’™0,ğ’™1,â€¦,ğ’™K)â‰”ğ’™subscriptğ’™0subscriptğ’™1â€¦subscriptğ’™ğ¾\bm{x}\coloneqq(\bm{x}_{0},\bm{x}_{1},\dots,\bm{x}_{K}). Here, ğ’‰kâ€‹nâ€‹(ğ’™k)â‰”ğ’‰kâ€‹(ğ’™k;ğƒnâ€‹k)â‰”subscriptğ’‰ğ‘˜ğ‘›subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜subscriptğ’‰ğ‘˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜subscriptğƒğ‘›ğ‘˜\bm{h}_{kn}(\bm{x}_{k})\coloneqq\bm{h}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k};\bm{\xi}_{nk}) is the local model of clientÂ kâˆˆ[K]ğ‘˜delimited-[]ğ¾k\in[K], which is parameterized by ğ’™ksubscriptğ’™ğ‘˜\bm{x}_{k} and extracts an (often lower-dimensional) representation of ğƒnâ€‹ksubscriptğƒğ‘›ğ‘˜\bm{\xi}_{nk}. These representations, or embeddings, are then sent to the server. The server, in turn, uses {ğ’‰kâ€‹nâ€‹(ğ’™k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘˜ğ‘›subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{\bm{h}_{kn}(\bm{x}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K} as input to Ï•nsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›\phi_{n}, which corresponds to the composition of the loss function and the server model and is parameterized by ğ’™0subscriptğ’™0\bm{x}_{0}.555The server often aggregates the representations ğ’‰kâ€‹nsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘˜ğ‘›\bm{h}_{kn} via some nonparameterized operation (for example, a sum or an average) before inputting them into the server model. We consider this aggregation to be included in Ï•nsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›\phi_{n}.

Most FL methods, including ours, assume that the server can communicate with all the clients and that the clients do not communicate with each other. These methods typically require many rounds of client-server communications. Such communications can significantly slow down training. In fact, they can become the main bottleneck during trainingÂ (Dean etÂ al., 2012, Lian etÂ al., 2017). To address this, a plethora of communication-efficient FL methods have been proposed. In particular, a popular technique to mitigate the communication overhead is lossy compression. Compression operators, or simply compressors, are operators that map a given vector into another vector that is easier to communicate (that is, requires fewer bits).

Optimization methods employing communication compression have seen great successÂ (Seide etÂ al., 2014, Alistarh etÂ al., 2017). Most of these works focus on the prevalent horizontal FL setup and thus consider gradient compression, as these are the vectors being communicated in the horizontal settingÂ (Alistarh etÂ al., 2018, Stich etÂ al., 2018). Yet, in vertical FL, the clients send representationsÂ {ğ’‰kâ€‹nâ€‹(ğ’™k)}subscriptğ’‰ğ‘˜ğ‘›subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜\{\bm{h}_{kn}(\bm{x}_{k})\} instead. In contrast to gradient compression, compressing these intermediate representations leads the compression-induced error to undergo a nonlinear function Ï•nsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›\phi_{n} before impacting gradient-based updates. Thus, compression in VFL is not covered by these works and our understanding of it remains limited. In fact, to the best of our knowledge, Castiglia etÂ al. (2022) is the only work providing convergence guarantees for compressed VFL. Yet, Castiglia etÂ al. (2022) employs a direct compression method, requiring the compression error to go to zero as the number of gradient steps Tğ‘‡T increases, achieving a ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) rate when the compression error is ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}). This makes the method inÂ Castiglia etÂ al. (2022) unsuitable for applications with strict per-round communication limitations, such as bandwidth constraints, and leads to the following question:

Can we design a communication-compressed VFL method that preserves the convergence rate of uncompressed methods without decreasing the amount of compression as training progresses?

1.1 Our contributions

In this work, we answer the question above in the affirmative. Our main contributions are as follows.

  • â€¢

    We propose error feedback compressed VFL (EFVFL), which leverages an error feedback technique to improve the stability of communication-compressed training in VFL.

  • â€¢

    We show that our method achieves a convergence rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/T) for nonconvex objectives under nonvanishing compression error, improving over the state-of-the-art ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) rate under ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}) compression error ofÂ Castiglia etÂ al. (2022), and matching the rate of the centralized setting. We further show that, under the Polyak-Åojasiewicz (PL) inequality, our method converges linearly, thus obtaining the first linearly convergent compressed VFL method. Unlike the method inÂ Castiglia etÂ al. (2022), EFVFL supports the use of private labels, broadening its applicability.

  • â€¢

    We run numerical experiments and observe empirically that our method improves the state-of-the-art, achieving a better communication efficiency than existing methods.

1.2 Related work

Communication-efficient FL.

The aforementioned communication bottleneck in FLÂ (Lian etÂ al., 2017) makes communication-efficient methods a particularly active area of research. FL methods often employ multiple local updates between rounds of communication, use only a subset of the clients at a timeÂ (McMahan etÂ al., 2017), or even update the global model asynchronouslyÂ (Xie etÂ al., 2019). Another line of research considers fully decentralized methodsÂ (Lian etÂ al., 2017), dispensing with the server and, instead, exploiting communications between clients. This can alleviate the bandwidth limit ensuing from the centralized role of the server. Another popular technique is lossy compression, which is the focus of this work.

Communication-compressed optimization methods can exploit different families of compressors. A popular choice is the family of unbiased compressorsÂ (Alistarh etÂ al., 2017), which is appealing in that its properties facilitate the theoretical analysis of the resulting methods. Yet, some widely adopted compressors do not belong to this class, such as top-kğ‘˜k sparsificationÂ (Alistarh etÂ al., 2018, Stich etÂ al., 2018) and deterministic roundingÂ (Sapio etÂ al., 2021). Thus, the broader family of contractive compressorsÂ (Beznosikov etÂ al., 2023) has recently attracted a lot of attention. Yet, methods employing them for direct compression are often prone to instability or even divergenceÂ (Beznosikov etÂ al., 2023). To address this, error feedback techniques have been proposed; first, as a heuristicÂ (Seide etÂ al., 2014), but, more recently, significant progress has been made on our theoretical understanding of the application of these methods to gradient compressionÂ (Stich etÂ al., 2018, Alistarh etÂ al., 2018, RichtÃ¡rik etÂ al., 2021). In the horizontal setting, some works have combined error feedback compression with the aforementioned communication-efficient techniques, such as communication-compressed fully decentralized methodsÂ (Koloskova etÂ al., 2019, Zhao etÂ al., 2022).

Vertical FL.

To mitigate the communication bottleneck in VFL, we often employ techniques akin to those used in horizontal FL. In particular, Liu etÂ al. (2022) performed multiple local updates between communication rounds, Chen etÂ al. (2020) updated the local models asynchronously, and Ying etÂ al. (2018) proposed a fully decentralized approach. Recently, Valdeira etÂ al. (2023) proposed a semi-decentralized method leveraging both client-server and client-client communications to avoid the slow convergence of fully-decentralized methods on large and sparse networks while alleviating the server bottleneck.

In this work, we focus on communication-compressed methods tailored to VFL. While, as mentioned above, most work in communication-compressed methods focuses on gradient compression and thus does not apply directly to VFL, recently, a few empirical works on VFL have employed compression. Namely, Khan etÂ al. (2022) compressed the local data before sending it to the server, where the model is trained, and Li etÂ al. (2020) proposed an asynchronous method with bidirectional (sparse) gradient compression. Nevertheless, Castiglia etÂ al. (2022), where direct compression is used, is the only work on compressed VFL with theoretical guarantees. For a more a detailed discussion on VFL, seeÂ Liu etÂ al. (2024), Yang etÂ al. (2023).

2.1 Error feedback

Error feedback is useful when using compressed communications to send a sequence of vectors {ğ’—t}superscriptğ’—ğ‘¡\{\bm{v}^{t}\} which we expect to converge. Unlike direct compression, where each ğ’—tsuperscriptğ’—ğ‘¡\bm{v}^{t} is compressed independently and ğ’â€‹(ğ’—t)ğ’superscriptğ’—ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{t}) acts as a surrogate for ğ’—tsuperscriptğ’—ğ‘¡\bm{v}^{t}, in error feedback compression, an estimate ğ’”tsuperscriptğ’”ğ‘¡\bm{s}^{t} is used as a surrogate. This surrogate is initialized as ğ’”0=ğ’â€‹(ğ’—0)superscriptğ’”0ğ’superscriptğ’—0\bm{s}^{0}=\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{0}) and is updated recursively as follows:

âˆ€tâ‰¥0:ğ’”t+1=ğ’”t+ğ’(ğ’—t+1âˆ’ğ’”t).\forall t\geq 0\colon\quad\bm{s}^{t+1}=\bm{s}^{t}+\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{t+1}-\bm{s}^{t}). (3)

Unlike ğ’â€‹(ğ’—t)ğ’superscriptğ’—ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{t}), ğ’”tsuperscriptğ’”ğ‘¡\bm{s}^{t} is not necessarily in the range of ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}. For example, if ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} uses sparsification, ğ’â€‹(ğ’—t)ğ’superscriptğ’—ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{t}) must be sparse, but ğ’”tsuperscriptğ’”ğ‘¡\bm{s}^{t} may not. Accumulating the compressed error of our surrogate allows ğ’”tsuperscriptğ’”ğ‘¡\bm{s}^{t} to â€œtrackâ€ ğ’—tsuperscriptğ’—ğ‘¡\bm{v}^{t}. Also, since the updatesÂ ğ’â€‹(ğ’—t+1âˆ’ğ’”t)ğ’superscriptğ’—ğ‘¡1superscriptğ’”ğ‘¡\mathcal{C}(\bm{v}^{t+1}-\bm{s}^{t}) are compressed, we preserve the communication cost of direct compression. Surrogate ğ’”tsuperscriptğ’”ğ‘¡\bm{s}^{t} is updated at both the machine (that is, client or server) sending the information and the one receiving it. Note that ğ’”tsuperscriptğ’”ğ‘¡\bm{s}^{t} can be seen as a Markovian compressor, as it depends only on ğ’—tsuperscriptğ’—ğ‘¡\bm{v}^{t} and ğ’”tâˆ’1superscriptğ’”ğ‘¡1\bm{s}^{t-1}.

3 Proposed method

To solve ProblemÂ (1) with a gradient-based method, we need to perform a forward and a backward pass at each step tğ‘¡t to compute the gradient of our objective function. In VFL, a standard uncompressed algorithm employing a single local update per communication round is mathematically equivalent to gradient descent.777When performing multiple local updates, we lose this mathematical equivalence. In that case, we instead get a parallel (block) coordinate descent method where the simultaneous updates use stale information about the other blocks of variables. This algorithm, which our method recovers if we set ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} to be the identity map, is as follows:

  • â€¢

    In the forward pass, each clientÂ kğ‘˜k computes ğ‘¯kâ€‹(ğ’™kt)subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t}) and sends it to the server, which then computes fâ€‹(ğ’™t)=Î¦â€‹(ğ‘¯â€‹(ğ’™t))ğ‘“superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡Î¦ğ‘¯superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡f(\bm{x}^{t})=\Phi\left(\bm{H}(\bm{x}^{t})\right).

  • â€¢

    In the backward pass, first, the server backpropagates through Î¦Î¦\Phi, obtaining âˆ‡0Î¦â€‹(ğ’™0t,{ğ‘¯kâ€‹(ğ’™kt)}k=1K)=âˆ‡0fâ€‹(ğ’™t)subscriptâˆ‡0Î¦superscriptsubscriptğ’™0ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘˜ğ‘¡ğ¾ğ‘˜1subscriptâˆ‡0ğ‘“superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\nabla_{0}\Phi(\bm{x}_{0}^{t},\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\}^{K}_{k=1})=\nabla_{0}f(\bm{x}^{t}) and âˆ‡kÎ¦â€‹({ğ‘¯kâ€‹(ğ’™kt)})subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜Î¦subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘˜ğ‘¡\nabla_{k}\Phi(\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\}), for all kğ‘˜k, where âˆ‡ksubscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜\nabla_{k} denotes the derivative with respect to blockÂ kğ‘˜k. Mini-batch.

For the sake of computation efficiency, we further allow for the use of mini-batch approximations of the objective. Without compression, or with direct compression, the use of mini-batches allows clientÂ kğ‘˜k to send only the entries of ğ‘¯kâ€‹(ğ’™k)subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}) corresponding to mini-batch â„¬âŠ†[N]â„¬delimited-[]ğ‘\mathcal{B}\subseteq[N], of size BğµB, denoted by ğ‘¯kâ€‹â„¬â€‹(ğ’™k)âˆˆâ„BÃ—Eksubscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜â„¬subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğµsubscriptğ¸ğ‘˜\bm{H}_{k\mathcal{B}}(\bm{x}_{k})\in\mathbb{R}^{B\times E_{k}}, instead of ğ‘¯kâ€‹(ğ’™k)âˆˆâ„NÃ—Eksubscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜superscriptâ„ğ‘subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k})\in\mathbb{R}^{N\times E_{k}}. Yet, our method provides all machines with an estimate for all the entries of {ğ‘¯kâ€‹(ğ’™k)}subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k})\} at all times, the error feedback states {ğ‘®k}subscriptğ‘®ğ‘˜\{\bm{G}_{k}\}. Therefore, our communications, needed to update ğ‘®ksubscriptğ‘®ğ‘˜\bm{G}_{k}, may not depend on Nğ‘N and BğµB at all. This is determined by our choice of ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C}.

Our mini-batch surrogates depend on the entries of ğ‘¯kâ€‹(ğ’™k)subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}) and ğ‘®ksubscriptğ‘®ğ‘˜\bm{G}_{k} corresponding to â„¬â„¬\mathcal{B}, ğ‘¯kâ€‹â„¬â€‹(ğ’™k)subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜â„¬subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜\bm{H}_{k\mathcal{B}}(\bm{x}_{k}), and ğ‘®kâ€‹â„¬subscriptğ‘®ğ‘˜â„¬\bm{G}_{k\mathcal{B}}. In AlgorithmÂ 1, we formulate our method in a general setting which allows for the compression of both {ğ‘¯kâ€‹(ğ’™k)}k=1Ksuperscriptsubscriptsubscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜ğ‘˜1ğ¾\{\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k})\}_{k=1}^{K} and ğ’™0subscriptğ’™0\bm{x}_{0}. 3.1 Adapting our method for handling private labels

In this section, we propose an adaptation of EFVFL to allow for private labels. That is, we remove the assumption that all clients hold Ï•nsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›\phi_{n}, which contains the label of ğƒnsubscriptğƒğ‘›\bm{\xi}_{n}. Instead, only the server holds the labels. Further, in this adaptation, the parameters of the server model, ğ’™0subscriptğ’™0\bm{x}_{0}, are not shared with the clients either.

Note that, without holding Ï•nsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›\phi_{n}, the clients cannot perform the entire forward pass locally. Instead, in this setting, the forward and backward pass over Ï•nsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›\phi_{n} take place at the server, while the forward and backward pass over ğ‘¯kâ€‹(ğ’™k)subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}) takes place at clientÂ kğ‘˜k. More precisely, in the forward pass, each clientÂ kğ‘˜k sends ğ‘ªksubscriptğ‘ªğ‘˜\bm{C}_{k} to the server, who holds ğ’™0subscriptğ’™0\bm{x}_{0} and the labels, and can thus compute the loss. Then, for the backward pass, the server backpropagates over its model and sends only the derivative of the loss function with respect to ğ‘®ksubscriptğ‘®ğ‘˜\bm{G}_{k} to each clientÂ kğ‘˜k. This requires replacing our surrogate of âˆ‡kfâ€‹(ğ’™t)subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜ğ‘“superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡\nabla_{k}f(\bm{x}^{t}) inÂ (4), which uses the exact local representation ğ‘¯kâ€‹(ğ’™k)subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜subscriptğ’™ğ‘˜\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}) at each client, by one based on our error feedback surrogates:

âˆ‡ktâ‰”âˆ‘i,j=1N,Ek[âˆ‡kÎ¦â€‹(ğ‘¯0â€‹(ğ’™0t),{ğ‘®jt}j=1K)]iâ€‹jâ€‹[âˆ‡ğ‘¯kâ€‹(ğ’™kt)]iâ€‹j:.â‰”subscriptsuperscriptbold-âˆ‡ğ‘¡ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ‘–ğ‘—1ğ‘subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜Î¦subscriptğ‘¯0superscriptsubscriptğ’™0ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘—ğ‘¡ğ¾ğ‘—1ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptdelimited-[]âˆ‡subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘˜ğ‘¡:ğ‘–ğ‘—absent\bm{\nabla}^{t}_{k}\coloneqq\sum_{i,j=1}^{N,E_{k}}\left[\nabla_{k}\Phi\left(\bm{H}_{0}(\bm{x}_{0}^{t}),\{\bm{G}_{j}^{t}\}^{K}_{j=1}\right)\right]_{ij}\left[\nabla\bm{H}_{k}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\right]_{ij:}. (5)

Note that we do not backpropagate through the error-feedback update.

More generally, we use the following (possibly) mini-batch update vector:

âˆ‡~ktâ‰”âˆ‘iâˆˆâ„¬tâˆ‘j=1Ek[âˆ‡kÎ¦â„¬tâ€‹(ğ‘¯0â€‹â„¬tâ€‹(ğ’™0t),{ğ‘®jâ€‹â„¬tt}j=1K)]iâ€‹jâ€‹[âˆ‡ğ‘¯kâ€‹â„¬tâ€‹(ğ’™kt)]iâ€‹j:.â‰”subscriptsuperscript~bold-âˆ‡ğ‘¡ğ‘˜subscriptğ‘–superscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ‘—1subscriptğ¸ğ‘˜subscriptdelimited-[]subscriptâˆ‡ğ‘˜subscriptÎ¦superscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡subscriptğ‘¯0superscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’™0ğ‘¡subscriptsuperscriptsuperscriptsubscriptğ‘®ğ‘—superscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡ğ‘¡ğ¾ğ‘—1ğ‘–ğ‘—subscriptdelimited-[]âˆ‡subscriptğ‘¯ğ‘˜superscriptâ„¬ğ‘¡superscriptsubscriptğ’™ğ‘˜ğ‘¡:ğ‘–ğ‘—absent\tilde{\bm{\nabla}}^{t}_{k}\coloneqq\sum_{i\in\mathcal{B}^{t}}\sum_{j=1}^{E_{k}}\left[\nabla_{k}\Phi_{\mathcal{B}^{t}}\left(\bm{H}_{0\mathcal{B}^{t}}(\bm{x}_{0}^{t}),\{\bm{G}_{j\mathcal{B}^{t}}^{t}\}^{K}_{j=1}\right)\right]_{ij}\left[\nabla\bm{H}_{k\mathcal{B}^{t}}(\bm{x}_{k}^{t})\right]_{ij:}.

We summarize the adaption of the EFVFL method to the private labels setting in AlgorithmÂ 2.

Allowing for private labels broadens the range of applications for our method, since many VFL applications require not only private features, but also private labels, rendering any method requiring public labels inapplicable. However, as we will see in SectionÂ 5.2, using surrogateÂ (5) instead of (4) can slow down convergence. Further, unlike AlgorithmÂ 1, which can be easily extendable to allow for multiple local updates at the clients between rounds of communication, AlgorithmÂ 2 works only for a single local update. This is because, for an VFL algorithm to perform multiple local updates, Ï•nsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›\phi_{n} and ğ’™0subscriptğ’™0\bm{x}_{0} must be available at the clients, so that the forward and backward passes over the server model and the loss function can be performed locally after each update.

4 Convergence guarantees

In this section, we provide convergence guarantees for EFVFL. We present our results for AlgorithmÂ 1 only, rather then stating them again for AlgorithmÂ 2, since they exhibit only a minor difference in LemmaÂ 1 and in main theorem, where the constant Kğ¾K is replaced with K+1ğ¾1K+1. We defer the details to AppendixÂ A.

This means that, despite reducing the total amount communications across the training, CVFL does not reduce the maximum amount of communications per round. In contrast, by allowing for nonvanishing compression, EFVFL ensures small communication cost at every round.

4.2 Under the PL inequality

In this section, we establish the linear convergence of EFVFL under the PL inequalityÂ (Polyak, 1963).

Assumption 5 (PL inequality).

We assume that there exists a positive constant Î¼ğœ‡\mu such that

âˆ€ğ’™âˆˆâ„d:âˆ¥âˆ‡f(ğ’™)âˆ¥2â‰¥2Î¼(f(ğ’™)âˆ’fâ‹†).\forall\bm{x}\in\mathbb{R}^{d}\colon\quad\lVert\nabla f(\bm{x})\rVert^{2}\geq 2\mu(f(\bm{x})-f^{\star}). (A5)

We resort to the following Lyapunov function to show linear convergence:

Vtâ‰”ğ”¼â€‹fâ€‹(ğ’™t)âˆ’fâ‹†+câ€‹ğ”¼â€‹Dt,â‰”subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘¡ğ”¼ğ‘“superscriptğ’™ğ‘¡superscriptğ‘“â‹†ğ‘ğ”¼superscriptğ·ğ‘¡V_{t}\coloneqq\mathbb{E}f(\bm{x}^{t})-f^{\star}+c\mathbb{E}D^{t}, (9)

where cğ‘c is a positive constant. We now present TheoremÂ 2.

Theorem 2.

Let {ğ±t}superscriptğ±ğ‘¡\{\bm{x}^{t}\} be a sequence generated by AlgorithmÂ 1, ğ’ğ’\mathcal{C} be a contractive compressorÂ (2), and fâ‹†>âˆ’âˆsuperscriptğ‘“â‹†f^{\star}>-\infty. If (A1) to (A5) hold, then, for Î·ğœ‚\eta such that Î·2â€‹L2â€‹(1âˆ’Î¼/L)+Î·â€‹Î¼â‰¤Î±2superscriptğœ‚2superscriptğ¿21ğœ‡ğ¿ğœ‚ğœ‡superscriptğ›¼2\eta^{2}L^{2}\left(1-\mu/L\right)+\eta\mu\leq\alpha^{2}, we have:

VTâ‰¤(1âˆ’Î·â€‹Î¼)Tâ€‹V0+ğ’ªâ€‹(Î·â€‹Ïƒ2B).subscriptğ‘‰ğ‘‡superscript1ğœ‚ğœ‡ğ‘‡subscriptğ‘‰0ğ’ªğœ‚superscriptğœ2ğµV_{T}\leq(1-\eta\mu)^{T}V_{0}+\mathcal{O}\left(\frac{\eta\sigma^{2}}{B}\right).
Proof.

See AppendixÂ C.2. âˆ

Since Î¼â‰¤Lğœ‡ğ¿\mu\leq L, we have that Î·âˆˆ(0,1/L)ğœ‚01ğ¿\eta\in(0,1/L) implies that 1âˆ’Î·â€‹Î¼âˆˆ(0,1)1ğœ‚ğœ‡011-\eta\mu\in(0,1). Hence, EFVFL converges linearly to a ğ’ªâ€‹(Ïƒ2)ğ’ªsuperscriptğœ2\mathcal{O}(\sigma^{2}) neighborhood around the global optimum.

5 Experiments

We compare EFVFL with two baselines: (1) standard VFL (SVFL), which corresponds to the method inÂ Liu etÂ al. (2022) and is mathematically equivalent to stochastic gradient descent when a single local update is used, and (2) CVFLÂ (Castiglia etÂ al., 2022), which recovers SVFL when an identity compressor is used (that is, without employing compression). All of our results correspond to the mean and standard deviation for five different seeds. We employ two popular compressors in our experiments.

5.1 Comparison with SVFL and CVFL

MNIST.

We train a shallow neural network (one hidden layer) on the MNIST digit recognition datasetÂ (LeCun etÂ al., 1998). The 28Ã—28282828\times 28 images in the original dataset ğ’Ÿğ’Ÿ\mathcal{D} are split into four local datasets ğ’Ÿksubscriptğ’Ÿğ‘˜\mathcal{D}_{k} of 14Ã—14141414\times 14 images, its quadrants (K=4ğ¾4K=4). The local modelsÂ ğ’‰kâ€‹nsubscriptğ’‰ğ‘˜ğ‘›\bm{h}_{kn} are maps ğ’—â†¦sigmoidâ€‹(ğ‘¾kâ€‹1â€‹ğ’—)maps-toğ’—sigmoidsubscriptğ‘¾ğ‘˜1ğ’—\bm{v}\mapsto\text{sigmoid}(\bm{W}_{k1}\bm{v}), with ğ‘¾kâ€‹1âˆˆâ„16Ã—196subscriptğ‘¾ğ‘˜1superscriptâ„16196\bm{W}_{k1}\in\mathbb{R}^{16\times 196}, and the server model is (ğ’—1,â€¦,ğ’—4)â†¦ğ‘¾2â€‹(âˆ‘k=14ğ’—k)maps-tosubscriptğ’—1â€¦subscriptğ’—4subscriptğ‘¾2superscriptsubscriptğ‘˜14subscriptğ’—ğ‘˜(\bm{v}_{1},\dots,\bm{v}_{4})\mapsto\bm{W}_{2}(\sum_{k=1}^{4}\bm{v}_{k}), with ğ‘¾2âˆˆâ„10Ã—16subscriptğ‘¾2superscriptâ„1016\bm{W}_{2}\in\mathbb{R}^{10\times 16}. We use cross-entropy loss. All three VFL optimizers use stepsizeÂ Î·=1ğœ‚1\eta=1 and full-batch gradients. In FigureÂ 2, we present the results for when EFVFL and CVFL employ topksubscripttopğ‘˜\text{top}_{k}, keeping 10%percent1010\%, 1%percent11\%, and 0.1%percent0.10.1\% of the entries, and when they employ qsgdssubscriptqsgdğ‘ \text{qsgd}_{s}, sending bâˆˆ{5,2,1}ğ‘521b\in\{5,2,1\} bits per entry, instead of the uncompressed b=32ğ‘32b=32. In both figures, we see that EFVFL outperforms SVFL and CVFL in communication efficiency. In terms of results per epoch, EFVFL significantly outperforms CVFL and, for a sufficiently large kğ‘˜k (for topksubscripttopğ‘˜\text{top}_{k}) or bğ‘b (for qsgdssubscriptqsgdğ‘ \text{qsgd}_{s}) EFVFL achieves a similar performance to SVFL. As predicted in SectionÂ 4, the train gradient squared norm during training goes to zero for EFVFL, as it does for SVFL, but not for CVFL.

ModelNet10.

We train a multi-view convolutional neural network (MVCNN)Â (Su etÂ al., 2015) on ModelNet10Â (Wu etÂ al., 2015), a dataset of three-dimensional CAD models. We use a preprocessed version of ModelNet10, where each sample is represented by 12 two-dimensional views. We assign a view per client (K=12ğ¾12K=12). For all three VFL optimizers, we use a batch sizeÂ B=128ğµ128B=128, a stepsizeÂ Î·=0.004ğœ‚0.004\eta=0.004, and a weight decay of 0.01. In FigureÂ 3, we present the results for when EFVFL and CVFL employ topksubscripttopğ‘˜\text{top}_{k}, keeping 20%percent2020\%, 2%percent22\%, and 0.2%percent0.20.2\% of the entries, and when they employ qsgdssubscriptqsgdğ‘ \text{qsgd}_{s}, with bâˆˆ{8,4,2}ğ‘842b\in\{8,4,2\}. We plot the train loss with respect to the number of epochs and the test accuracy with respect to the communication cost. We observe that, for EFVFL, the training loss decreases more rapidly than for CVFL. Further, if the compression is not excessively aggressive, EFVFL performs similarly to SVFL. In terms of communication efficiency, EFVFL outperforms both SVFL and CVFL.

CIFAR-10.

We train a model based on a residual neural network, ResNet18Â (He etÂ al., 2016), on CIFAR-10Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009). More precisely, we divide each image into four quadrants and allocate one quadrant to each client (K=4ğ¾4K=4), with each client using a ResNet18 model as its local model. The server model is a multilayer perceptron with three layers. All three VFL optimizers use a batch sizeÂ B=128ğµ128B=128, a stepsizeÂ Î·=0.01ğœ‚0.01\eta=0.01, and a weight decay of 0.01. In FigureÂ 4, we present the results for when EFVFL and CVFL employ topksubscripttopğ‘˜\text{top}_{k}, keeping 10%percent1010\%, 1%percent11\%, and 0.1%percent0.10.1\% of the entries, and when they employ qsgdssubscriptqsgdğ‘ \text{qsgd}_{s}, with bâˆˆ{4,2,1}ğ‘421b\in\{4,2,1\}. We plot the train loss with respect to the number of epochs and the test accuracy with respect to the communication cost. Regarding the results with respect to the number of epochs, EFVFL achieves a similar performance to that of SVFL, significantly outperforming CVFL. In terms of communication efficiency, EFVFL outperforms both SVFL and CVFL.

5.2 Performance under private labels

In this section, we run experiments on the adaption of EFVFL to handle private labels, proposed in SectionÂ 3.1.

InÂ Castiglia etÂ al. (2022), the authors assume that the labels are available at all clients and do not propose an adaptation of CVFL to deal with private labels. Yet, to get a baseline for a compressed VFL method allowing for label privacy, we adapt CVFL in a similar manner to how we adapt EFVFL (that is, sending back the derivative from the server to the clients, instead of Ï•nsubscriptitalic-Ï•ğ‘›\phi_{n} and ğ’™0subscriptğ’™0\bm{x}_{0}, and without backpropagating through the compression operator).

We run an experiment on MNIST, training the same shallow neural network as in model as in SectionÂ 5.1, with all the same settings, except for the use of batch sizeÂ B=1024ğµ1024B=1024. Further, we train another ResNet18-based model, now with a linear server model (a single layer), on CIFAR-100Â (Krizhevsky etÂ al., 2009). For all the optimizers, we use an initial stepsize of Î·=0.01ğœ‚0.01\eta=0.01 and a cosine annealing scheduler with a minimum stepsize of 1/10011001/100 the initial value and use a batch sizeÂ B=128ğµ128B=128 and a weight decay of 0.010.010.01. The compressed-communication methods employ topksubscripttopğ‘˜\text{top}_{k}, keeping 5%percent55\% of the entries.

In FigureÂ 5, we observe that, although the modified EFVFL for handling private labels converges noticeably slower than the original method, it still performs effectively. For both the MNIST experiment and the CIFAR-100 experiment, we see that, while adapting CVFL to handle private labels leads to a severe drop in performance, EFVFL slows down much less noticeably. In fact, for the MNIST experiment, EFVFL with private labels still outperforms CVFL, even with public labels.

5.3 Performance under multiple local updates

As mentioned earlier, some VFL works employ Q>1ğ‘„1Q>1 local updates per roundÂ (Liu etÂ al., 2022), using stale information from the other machines. We now show that, although our analysis focuses on the case where each client performs a single local update at each round of communications (that is, Q=1ğ‘„1Q=1), EFVFL performs well in the Q>1ğ‘„1Q>1 case too. In particular, to study the performance of EFVFL when carrying out multiple local updates, we train an MVCNN on ModelNet10 and a ResNet18 on CIFAR-10, on the same setups as in SectionÂ 5.1.

For ModelNet10, all three VFL optimizers use a batch sizeÂ B=128ğµ128B=128, a stepsizeÂ Î·=0.004ğœ‚0.004\eta=0.004, and a weight decay of 0.01. Further, we use a learning rate scheduler, halving the learning rate at epochs 50 and 75. The results are presented in FigureÂ 6(a) and FigureÂ 6(b). For CIFAR-10, all three VFL optimizers use a batch sizeÂ B=128ğµ128B=128, a stepsizeÂ Î·=0.0025ğœ‚0.0025\eta=0.0025, and a weight decay of 0.01. Further, we use a learning rate scheduler, halving the learning rate at epochs 40, 60, and 80. The results are presented in FigureÂ 6(c) and FigureÂ 6(d).

For both ModelNet10 and CIFAR-10, we see that, similarly to the Q=1ğ‘„1Q=1 case, our method outperforms SVFL and CVFL in communication efficiency. In terms of results per epoch, EFVFL performs similarly to SVFL and significantly better than CVFL. Interestingly, for the CIFAR-10 task, EFVFL even outperforms SVFL with respect to the number of epochs. We suspect this may be due to the fact that compression helps to mitigate the overly greedy nature of the parallel updates based on stale information.

6 Conclusions

In this work, we proposed EFVFL, a method for compressed vertical federated learning. Our method leverages an error feedback mechanism to achieve a ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/T) convergence rate, improving upon the state-of-the-art rate of ğ’ªâ€‹(1/T)ğ’ª1ğ‘‡\mathcal{O}(1/\sqrt{T}). Numerical experiments further demonstrate the faster convergence of our method. We further show that, under the PL inequality, our method converges linearly and introduce a modification of EFVFL supporting the use of private labels. In the future, it would be interesting to study the use of error feedback based compression methods for VFL in the fully-decentralized and semi-decentralized settings, as well as combining it with privacy mechanisms, such as differential privacy.
